text: Sorry i took a little brake of nuke last days... I start bake back today and give you news about my demo shot
Thank you

Hey Eric, 

I apologize for taking a couple of days to get back! 
Work hasn’t let up in advertising - even with the pandemic.

Yes, starting out as a junior right now is extremely difficult. For a company to onboard a junior under these circumstances would be very risky, so it’s understandable that hiring would be down.
These pandemic circumstances are extremely unique, and it’s nothing any VFX house has ever dealt with. 
These companies will need to stabilize before they considering hiring anyone, junior or senior, right now.

Keeping your skills fresh, and practicing the fundamentals is very beneficial though. I’m glad that you’re still hungry. When these social restrictions begin to fade away, being hungry and sharp will go a long way.
Sure
As for your reel, Eric. It’s impressive for a junior
Or someone applying for junior positions. It demonstrates the fundamentals very cleanly and concisely.
To be honest, I don’t have a problem with any of those shots. They’re demonstrating vital core skills, and doing it creatively.

So for what you have, I’d recommend tightening up the timing. Cutting down to as close to a minute as possible. 1-2 minutes is ok.

Your breakdowns are break, but there’s room for you to edit down the time for each shot’s before, after, and breakdown.
Breakdowns are great**

I don’t see a need for flashy intros, and the music isn’t distracting, so what you have, I feel, is enough for a junior position.

The rest is timing and luck
If you can edit down what you have, and include a couple more disciplines, it would only help
And the new shots i can work out... what kind of Shots are you suggesting

Demonstrating some sharp, close, detailed beauty work is a good thing to see.

Breaking down a photo real CG/Live Action shot would be great as well.  If you can get creative, and get a good camera, track in some CG elements photorealistically, and show a breakdown demonstrating your understanding of multipass EXRs, that’s good to see.

It’s silly, but a good-difficult screen comp on maybe an old TV, or complicated cell phone shows tracking and comp skills that wouldn’t be used elsewhere, and screen comps are a big responsibility for a lot of juniors.


Demonstrating what you expect that studio to ask from you, ultimately, is what you want to put on your reel.

You’ll likely never know exactly what that is, so the best you can do is demonstrate an understanding of what you feel you need to demonstrate to meet their needs - as well as show that you’re ambitious and hungry.
You’ll need to keep it snappy though. That’s a lot to include, so do your best to keep it under 2 minutes, and have a pace that won’t let the viewer’s mind wonder.

I can show you my last advertising reel for pacing, but I wouldn’t follow it in format.

My reel is mostly a sizzle reel, with a couple of breakdowns at the end. The pacing and speed is very effective, but yours should be much heavier on showing quick to-the-point breakdowns.
Here’s my last before I went into film. Although it’s a sizzle reel, I make sure to demonstrate a wide variety of techniques.
<https://vimeo.com/330374407|https://vimeo.com/330374407>

text:
Of course, if any of the language that I am using is unclear, please ask lots of questions. I understand this is a lot of information at once.

I’m happy to answer any questions you have to help guide you :)

Having the tightest possible reel out of this viral pandemic is the best you can do, and I’ll help you with that. 
Staying in contact with recruiters, and scouting out who may be staffing up is a very good idea too. I can help you wit that, if it become difficult, as well.
I totally understand thanks

No worries, Eric. 

I’ll do better to write back within 24 hours.

In the meantime, feel free to keep asking questions. If you want me to go over any work with you, or need some direction with your compositing, feel free to reach out. 

I’m looking forward to seeing what you can create during these times!

So the shot i do right now :

I have 2 videos that I camera tracked with scene + 3d. 
- first one I use only the camera and a man lifting a big tractor tire. 
- second one I do same 3d tracking.. 
1- I ll use it as background and the parking ground. So I export as fbx in maya.

Both shit are undistort bfore exporting in maya and as well degrain. 

I will use 3d CG car asset rig and textured in arnold .

I will use a card export to maya with the roto of the lifter and the camera from the lifter scene to animate car the tire wheel will spin a bit on the ground before the lifting.

I will export the render as .exr with rendre passes in nuke. And shuffle them ... color correct etc.

On the background scene I will use camera from lifting shot with the roto of the guy now fit with the car. 

I want to convert shots because they are daytime.. I will do evening light corrections.
Merge them together. Add lights for car and like street lamp effects.. windows lights on some.

Adding the friction smoke on the ground and car and scene with a little fire affect subtitle...
